description: Simple, practical nutrition advice that fits your real life—no complicated diets required.

articles.title: The 5-Minute Meal Prep Rule That Actually Works
articles.description: Stop prepping meals. Start prepping ingredients. This one rule saves time and sanity.
articles.content:
Meal prep sounds great in theory. In reality, it often turns into a Sunday project that leaves you with a sink full of dishes and leftovers you're tired of by Tuesday.

Here's the truth that actually works: Stop prepping meals. Start prepping ingredients.

The 5-Minute Rule: Spend five minutes on these three tasks, and you'll have real meals all week with zero daily effort.

1. Cook one protein: Grill a few chicken breasts, brown ground beef, or hard-boil a half-dozen eggs.
2. Chop two veggies: Bell peppers and onions go with everything. Store them in one container.
3. Make one sauce: Whisk together olive oil, lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Or just have good mayo on hand.

Why this works: When you're hungry at noon, you're not cooking. You're assembling. Protein + veggies + sauce = a real meal in three minutes. No thinking, no clean-up, no sad desk lunch.

The 5-minute investment saves you from expensive takeout and that 'I guess I'll just skip it' feeling. Try it this week. Set a timer. You'll be done before your coffee brews.

articles.title: The 3 Food Combinations That Kill the Afternoon Slump
articles.description: Eat for energy, not just fullness. These combos keep your blood sugar steady all afternoon.
articles.content:
You eat lunch, feel full for an hour, and then crash so hard you need coffee just to function. Sound familiar?

The problem isn't how much you ate. It's that you ate for fullness, not energy.

Here are three food combinations that solve the afternoon crash by keeping your blood sugar steady.

Combination 1: The Apple Sleeve
What it is: An apple sliced and slathered with almond or peanut butter.
Why it works: The fiber in the apple slows digestion. The fat in the nut butter smooths out the energy release. No spike, no crash. Just hours of steady fuel.

Combination 2: The Traveler's Plate
What it is: A few hard-boiled eggs and a small container of berries or cherry tomatoes.
Why it works: Protein from the eggs signals fullness to your brain. The low-sugar carbs from the fruit provide quick energy without the insulin spike. It's the original fast food, and it fits in your bag.

Combination 3: The No-Think Salad
What it is: A handful of greens, leftover grilled chicken (from your 5-minute prep!), a drizzle of olive oil, and a pinch of salt.
Why it works: This is the gold standard. Vegetables give you micronutrients. Healthy fat (olive oil) supports your brain. Lean protein rebuilds muscle and stabilizes mood. It takes two minutes to throw together.

The 3-Day Energy Challenge:
For the next three days, build every lunch around these combinations. Notice how you feel at 3 p.m. You might not need that coffee.

articles.title: 3 Signs Your Gut is Trying to Tell You Something
articles.description: Bloating, cravings, skin issues—your gut communicates. Here's what to listen for.
articles.content:
Your gut does more than process food. It houses 70% of your immune system and produces 90% of your serotonin—the chemical that helps you feel calm and happy.

When something's off, your gut doesn't send a memo. It sends signals. Here are three signs to notice and what they actually mean.

Sign 1: You bloat after 'healthy' meals.
You eat a salad or some raw veggies and immediately feel like a balloon.
What it means: You might have trouble digesting raw fiber. It's not a character flaw; it's just your system.
The fix: Cook your veggies. Steaming or roasting breaks down the tough cell walls, making them easier to digest. Same nutrients, zero discomfort.

Sign 2: You crave sugar right after eating.
You finish a satisfying meal, and your brain immediately starts scanning for something sweet.
What it means: An imbalance in your gut bacteria. The 'bad' bacteria are sending cravings signals to your brain to get the sugar they feed on.
The fix: Add one forkful of something fermented to your plate. Sauerkraut, kimchi, a dill pickle, or a spoonful of plain yogurt. It introduces beneficial bacteria that crowd out the sugar-craving ones. Do this for a week and notice if the cravings quiet down.

Sign 3: Your skin is breaking out for no reason.
You haven't changed your skincare routine, but your skin is suddenly angry.
What it means: Skin inflammation often starts in the gut. When your digestive lining is irritated, it can trigger inflammation anywhere—including your face.
The fix: Drink one extra glass of water today. Then add a serving of leafy greens to one meal for five days. Hydration and fiber are the simplest ways to calm gut irritation. Watch what happens to your skin.

Listen to those signals. Your gut isn't being difficult—it's communicating. The fix is often simpler than you think.
